meanings.definition: Pharoses (noun): plural form of pharos, a tall tower with a light used as a beacon for ships at sea.
meanings.sent1: The pharoses along the coast helped sailors navigate safely through the night.
meanings.sent2: The ancient pharoses were essential for maritime navigation in the past.
meanings.sent3: The pharoses stood tall like guardians of the sea, guiding ships to shore.
meanings.sent4: The pharoses pierced the darkness, offering a guiding light to lost sailors.
meanings.sent5: The pharoses loomed large, casting their light across the vast ocean.

meanings.definition: Pharoses (verb): third person singular present of pharose, to guide or signal with a pharos.
meanings.sent1: He pharoses the ships with precision, ensuring their safe passage through the storm.
meanings.sent2: She pharoses the way for the fleet, leading them to safety with her beacon.
meanings.sent3: The lighthouse keeper pharoses the incoming vessels, like a modern-day hero of the sea.
meanings.sent4: The captain pharoses his crew through the treacherous waters, never faltering in his duty.
meanings.sent5: Using the lighthouse, he pharoses the ships to shore, guiding them with unwavering light.

meanings.definition: Pharoses (adjective): describing something related to or resembling a pharos.
meanings.sent1: The pharoses design of the new lighthouse was both functional and beautiful.
meanings.sent2: The pharoses structure of the tower made it a striking landmark along the coast.
meanings.sent3: The pharoses architecture of the lighthouse captured the attention of all who passed by.
meanings.sent4: The pharoses glow of the beacon could be seen from miles away, a true marvel of engineering.
meanings.sent5: The pharoses appearance of the lighthouse added a touch of elegance to the rugged coastline.
